etymologies: Middle English: from Old French mirour, based on Latin mirare ?look at?. Early senses also included ?a crystal used in magic? and ?a person deserving imitation?

definitions: a surface, typically of glass coated with a metal amalgam, which reflects a clear image

examples.text: he checked his appearance in the mirror

definitions: a thing regarded as accurately representing something else

examples.text: the stage is supposed to be the mirror of life

definitions: a site on a network which stores the contents copied from another site

examples.text: the company now has a mirror site in Taiwan

short_definitions: site which stores copy of another

definitions: (of a surface) show a reflection of

examples.text: the clear water mirrored the sky
his own views mirrored those of his followers

definitions: keep a copy of the contents of (a network site) at another site, typically in order to improve accessibility

examples.text: his site was mirrored at several colleges around the United States

definitions: store copies of data in (two or more hard disks) for protection

examples.text: the second drive is set up for disk mirroring

short_definitions: store data copies in hard disks
